info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades semifinal game 1.

double_jeopardy_round: MAKE YOUR OWN SPY NOVEL TITLES

(1, 1).clue: Sanskrit texts call this ocean Ratnakara, the mine of jewels

(2, 1).clue: In London Paula Radcliffe ran a 2:15:25 in this race in 2003; it's still the world record

(3, 1).clue: Members of the agave, lily & cactus families are this type of plant whose fleshy leaves are able to store water

(4, 1).clue: In 2013 Variety reported "This is the End" was the last movie rented from this once-mighty chain

(5, 1).clue: In the one-man show "You're Welcome America", Will Ferrell spoofed this president

(6, 1).clue: Where to vacay?  This Mediterranean region:"I ARRIVE"

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a globe on the monitor.)  From the shores of Antarctica, the Pacific Ocean stretches north over 9,000 miles to this narrow passage

(2, 2).clue: In 2009, on her back, feet first, American Erin Hamlin broke a 16-year German reign in this winter sport

(3, 2).clue: Looking for a climber with fragrant flowers?  Plant the star type of this shrub

(4, 2).clue: In 2009 service was no longer state of the art at the last brick & mortar stores of this alliterative electronics chain

(5, 2).clue: The singing killers & would-be killers of "Assassins" include Oswald, Booth & this 1980s attempter

(6, 2).clue: Type of agreement made before the vows:"A TRIPLE PUN"

(1, 3).clue: Originally an adjective, it's now a noun referring to a deep-sea vessel like a submarine or bathyscaphe

(2, 3).clue: At the '88 worlds, skater Kurt Browning was the first in competition to land a jump with this many revolutions

(3, 3).clue: This hybrid lemon tree bears the surname of the guy from the U.S.D.A. who brought it to the U.S. in 1908

(4, 3).clue: Let's go back in time--he made 9,000 of the cars named for him before running off the road in 1982

(5, 3).clue: In 2014 Bryan Cranston made his Broadway debut in "All The Way", a drama about this president's first year in office

(6, 3).clue: Pop its cork & get a"GRIP ON DEMON"

(1, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a map on the monitor.)  The Atlantic Ocean's deepest point, at about 27,500 feet, is located In the trench bearing the name of this island

(2, 4).clue: In 2007 Merlene Ottey, born in this island nation known for sprinters, ran an 11.64 100 meters... at age 47

(3, 4).clue: This flower does well in partial shade but can be exposed to full sun

(4, 4).clue: In 1991 this "directional" airline flew off into the sunset after 64 years

(5, 4).clue: "Politics & Poker" & "I Love a Cop" are songs in this musical about a big-city mayor

(6, 4).clue: Endow a new chemistry building there:"THROAT MUD"

(1, 5).clue: What scientists technically call insanely weird creatures live near hydrothermal these on the ocean floor

(2, 5).clue: In 6 straight world track & field championships 1983 to 1997, this Ukrainian was your winner in the pole vault

(3, 5).clue: This process of punching holes & removing small plugs of soil from a lawn helps to improve nutrient & water absorption

(4, 5).clue: In 2009 Toys "R" Us scooped up the remains of this 2-letter retailer

(5, 5).clue: It's Peter Morgan's play about a revealing series of 1977 interviews

(6, 5).clue: Your kid is one, even past infancy:"BRATTY BUDS FUN"

(1, 1).clue: The + a Jewish holiday in which the story of Exodus is retold + a musical term for a gradual increase in volume

(2, 1).clue: This word denoting a counterpart is German & means "double-walker"

(3, 1).clue: This American known for his portraits was born in Italy to the former Mary Newbold Singer

(5, 1).clue: In a letter to a 5-year-old boy, she wrote the story of 4 little rabbits named Flopsy, Mopsy, Cottontail & Peter

(1, 2).clue: The + a green knight-battling Round Tabler + milk substitute for babies, such as Enfamil

(3, 2).clue: This French word for "lounge" was used for exhibits of artworks; famous ones were "D'automne" & "Des Independants"

(5, 2).clue: (I'm Ben Mankiewiczof Turner Classic Movies.)  Hitchcock's reply to an angry dad who wrote that his daughter was  refusing to shower after seeing this 1960 film? "Send her to the dry cleaners"

(6, 2).clue: PS can stand for picosecond, this fraction of a second

(1, 3).clue: The + our 9th president's last name + a "diplomatic" term for a correct method of medical treatment

(2, 3).clue: Grammatically, in "When Al headbutted a lamppost, he got a concussion", "Al" is this of "he", & Al is stupid

(3, 3).clue: Nature morte (literally "dead nature") is another name for this genre of painting

(4, 3).clue: His 1954 & 1955 supporting actor Emmys were for "The Jackie Gleason Show"

(5, 3).clue: This explorer wrote to his friend J.M. Barrie in 1912, "We have accomplished our object in reaching the pole"

(6, 3).clue: This justice said of pornography, "I know it when I see it", & you'll know him when you see him

(1, 4).clue: The + a Mongol emperor's poetic palace + a type of papal teaching letter first issued in 1740

(2, 4).clue: Adjective for the perfect embodiment of something. Or something a Dionne kid must have

(3, 4).clue: Da Vinci used both chiaroscuro & this, Italian for "smoked", to gradually transition hues

(4, 4).clue: He made 'em laugh & won for his "Colgate Comedy Hour" work

(5, 4).clue: In this 1845 story, the stolen title object has been hidden in plain sight

(1, 5).clue: The + a 35-year "Price is Right" host + an act of reasoning from the general to the specific

(2, 5).clue: From the Latin for "uncertain", it refers to a judgment based on one's whim rather than on a rule

(3, 5).clue: Joseph Cornell took these small display cases into the realm of Surrealist art

(4, 5).clue: In 1952 this comedian won the "Best Actor" Emmy; in 2014 his "hour" came as he passed away at 91

(5, 5).clue: He wrote to his muse Georgia O'Keeffe, "how I wanted to photograph you--the hands--the mouth--& eyes"

(0, 0).clue: Written about the U.S. occupation of the Philippines, a Kipling poem said, "take up" this now-controversial phrase
